intro: Perezia poeppigii, commonly known as the desert bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its leaves are usually narrow and succulent, helping to reduce water loss. The flowers, which can be blue or purple, bloom in late spring or early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
